translations.fr: Faire une course contre la montre

idioms.definition: Before the scheduled, expected, or necessary time.
examples: They finished the project ahead of time, much to everyone's surprise.
If you book your tickets ahead of time, you might get a discount.

idioms.definition: To stop doing something, often because you've had enough or reached a point of no return. Can also refer to ending a relationship.
examples: After working for twelve hours, he decided to call it quits.
They've been arguing for months, I think they're going to call it quits.

idioms.definition: A past period that is remembered fondly as being better than the present.
examples: My grandparents often talk about the good old days.
Sometimes I miss the good old days when life seemed simpler.

idioms.definition: To use as much time as you need; not to hurry.

There's no need to hurry, take your time deciding.

idioms.definition: To do something quickly or more often to compensate for a period of inactivity or absence.

They spent the whole weekend together to make up for lost time after she returned from her trip.

idioms.definition: There is an urgent need to act quickly.

We have a tight deadline, so there's no time to lose on this task.

idioms.definition: To do or say something too soon, before the appropriate time.

translations.fr: Vendre la peau de l'ours avant de l'avoir tué

idioms.definition: To lose an opportunity by being too slow to act.

idioms.definition: To make the most of the present moment; to live for today (from 'Carpe Diem').

translations.fr: Profiter du jour présent (Carpe Diem) / Saisir l'occasion

idioms.definition: To go back in time to change something or revisit a past situation.

idioms.idiom: Don't put all your eggs in one basket

translations.de: Nicht alles auf eine Karte setzen.
translations.fr: Ne pas mettre tous ses œufs dans le même panier.

idioms.definition: To take advantage of an opportunity when it is available and favorable.
examples: The job offer is great; you should strike while the iron's hot and accept it.
The market is good for selling right now, so we should strike while the iron's hot.

translations.de: Das Eisen schmieden, solange es heiß ist

idioms.definition: Occasionally; sometimes, but not often.

We go out for dinner once in a while to celebrate special occasions.

idioms.definition: At the last possible moment or very late.

idioms.idiom: Strike while the iron is hot.

examples: The market is good right now, so we should strike while the iron is hot and launch our new product.

translations.de: Das Eisen schmieden, solange es heiß ist.
translations.fr: Battre le fer tant qu'il est chaud.

idioms.definition: To work or study late into the night.
examples: I had to burn the midnight oil to finish the report on time before the deadline.

translations.de: Bis tief in die Nacht arbeiten / Die Nächte durcharbeiten.
translations.fr: Travailler tard dans la nuit / Veiller tard.

idioms.definition: It's too late; an opportunity has passed.
examples: I wanted to apply for that job, but the deadline was yesterday – the ship has sailed.
You should have invested years ago; for that company, the ship has sailed.

translations.fr: Le train est passé / L'occasion est perdue

idioms.definition: Having ideas or products that are too advanced or innovative to be appreciated in the present.
examples: Many artists whose work is now revered were considered ahead of their time.
His inventions were truly ahead of their time, but the technology wasn't ready.

idioms.definition: To wish to return to a moment in the past, often to correct a mistake or relive a memory.
examples: If I could turn back time, I’d tell her how I really felt.
Nostalgia makes us dream of turning back time.

idioms.definition: Raining very heavily.

idioms.definition: A lot of anger or worry about something unimportant.
examples: Their argument over who left the light on was just a storm in a teacup; they'll be fine.

translations.fr: Une tempête dans un verre d'eau

idioms.definition: Whatever happens; no matter what the weather or circumstances.
examples: I'll be there for you, come rain or shine, no matter how difficult things get.
The farmer's market is open every Saturday, come rain or shine.

translations.fr: Qu'il pleuve ou qu'il fasse beau

idioms.idiom: Every cloud has a silver lining

She tries to remember that every cloud has a silver lining during tough times.

translations.de: Jedes Unglück hat auch etwas Gutes
translations.fr: À quelque chose malheur est bon

idioms.idiom: Every cloud has a silver lining.
idioms.definition: Every difficult or unpleasant situation has some positive aspect or possibility.
examples: I lost my job, but every cloud has a silver lining; now I can pursue my dream career.
Even after the storm, remember that every cloud has a silver lining.

translations.de: Jedes Unglück hat auch etwas Gutes.
translations.fr: À quelque chose malheur est bon.

idioms.definition: A lot of anger or worry about something unimportant.
examples: Their argument about the dirty dishes was just a storm in a teacup.
Don't worry, it's just a storm in a teacup, they'll be friends again tomorrow.

translations.fr: Une tempête dans un verre d'eau.

idioms.definition: To endure a difficult period or crisis.
examples: The company managed to weather the storm during the economic recession.
They had to weather the storm of criticism after the scandal.

idioms.definition: Someone who is only a friend when times are good and abandons you when things get difficult.
examples: When I lost all my money, I realized she was just a fair-weather friend.
He only shows up when things are going well; he's a true fair-weather friend.

idioms.definition: To be extremely happy.
examples: After she won the lottery, she was on cloud nine for weeks.
He's been on cloud nine ever since he got engaged.

idioms.definition: To postpone an invitation or offer to a later time.
examples: I can't make it to dinner tonight, but can I take a rain check?
I'm busy this weekend, so I'll have to take a rain check on your offer to go hiking.

idioms.definition: A period of peace or quiet before a period of great activity, trouble, or excitement.

The quiet morning felt like the calm before the storm of the busy workday.

idioms.definition: In the world; anywhere on Earth (used for emphasis or universality).
examples: It was the most beautiful sight under the sun.
We've tried every possible solution under the sun to fix this problem.

translations.fr: Sous le soleil / Sur toute la Terre

idioms.definition: To aim high and try to achieve something difficult or ambitious.
examples: Don't be afraid to reach for the stars in your career.
With hard work and dedication, you can reach for the stars.

translations.fr: Viser les étoiles / Ambitionner de grandes choses

idioms.definition: A lot of anger or worry about something unimportant.
examples: Their argument over who left the lights on was just a storm in a teacup; they'll be fine tomorrow.
It was a storm in a teacup about a minor scheduling conflict, easily resolved.

translations.fr: une tempête dans un verre d'eau

idioms.definition: A new burst of energy or motivation after a period of tiredness or difficulty.
examples: I was exhausted halfway through the marathon, but then I got my second wind.
After a short break, the team got a second wind and finished the project strong.

translations.de: Einen zweiten Wind bekommen / Neue Kraft schöpfen

idioms.definition: To be perfectly well or healthy.
examples: After a good night's sleep, I feel as right as rain.

examples: I was about to announce my promotion, but my colleague stole my thunder by announcing hers first.

idioms.definition: Raining very heavily.

We had to cancel the picnic because it started raining cats and dogs.

idioms.definition: To be unrealistic, dreamy, or impractical.
examples: He always has his head in the clouds, dreaming about becoming a rock star.
You need to take your head out of the clouds and focus on reality.

translations.de: Den Kopf in den Wolken haben
translations.fr: Avoir la tête dans les nuages

idioms.definition: To resolve a misunderstanding or disagreement, often by discussing it openly.
examples: We had an argument, but after a long talk, we managed to clear the air.
It's important to clear the air and address any issues directly.

idioms.definition: To be very easy to do.
examples: Learning to use the new software was a breeze.
With a good recipe, baking this cake will be a breeze.

idioms.definition: Very clear and easy to understand.
examples: Her instructions were clear as a bell.
After the fog lifted, the view was clear as a bell.

translations.fr: Clair comme de l'eau de roche

idioms.definition: To hear a rumor or a piece of information that was meant to be secret.
examples: The police got wind of the escape plan.
If the competitors get wind of our new product, they might try to copy it.

idioms.definition: To do something very easily and quickly.
examples: He breezed through his exams without even studying much.
With her experience, she should breeze through the project.

translations.de: Etwas leicht schaffen, im Handumdrehen erledigen
translations.fr: Passer à travers facilement, réussir sans difficulté

idioms.definition: Out of danger or difficulty.
examples: After the surgery, the patient is still not completely out of the woods.
The company is struggling, but we hope to be out of the woods soon.

translations.de: Aus dem Gröbsten raus sein, über den Berg sein
translations.fr: Être tiré d'affaire, être hors de danger

idioms.idiom: Let the chips fall where they may
idioms.definition: To allow events to unfold without trying to control the outcome, accepting whatever happens.
examples: I've done all I can; now I'll just let the chips fall where they may.
He decided to tell the truth and let the chips fall where they may.

translations.de: Es kommen lassen, wie es kommt
translations.fr: Laisser faire le destin, advienne que pourra

idioms.definition: Someone or something new, refreshing, and different from what existed before.
examples: Her innovative ideas were a breath of fresh air for the stagnant company.
After all the drama, his calm presence was a real breath of fresh air.

translations.de: Ein Hauch frischer Luft / Eine willkommene Abwechslung

idioms.definition: When one bad thing happens, a lot of other bad things tend to happen at the same time; also used for good things, but less commonly.
examples: First, my car broke down, then I lost my wallet. When it rains, it pours!
I got a flat tire, then a parking ticket, and then I was late for work. Talk about 'when it rains, it pours'.

translations.de: Ein Unglück kommt selten allein / Wenn es regnet, schüttet es
translations.fr: Un malheur n'arrive jamais seul / Quand ça va mal, ça va très mal

idioms.definition: To be lost in thought or daydreaming; to have impractical ideas.
examples: He always has his head in the clouds, dreaming of unrealistic inventions.

translations.de: Den Kopf in den Wolken haben
translations.fr: Avoir la tête dans les nuages

idioms.definition: To be alert and watchful, especially for potential danger or opportunities.
examples: The captain told the crew to keep a weather eye open for storms.
You should keep a weather eye open for good deals when shopping online.

translations.de: Ein Auge offen halten / Wachsam sein
translations.fr: Être sur ses gardes / Rester vigilant

idioms.definition: Someone or something that brings happiness into the lives of others, often in difficult times.
examples: My little niece is a ray of sunshine, always making everyone smile.
Her positive attitude was a ray of sunshine during the challenging project.

idioms.definition: To spoil someone's plans or enthusiasm.
examples: I don't want to rain on your parade, but the restaurant is closed today.
He always manages to rain on everyone's parade with his negativity.

idioms.definition: To take attention or credit away from someone else, often by doing something similar first.
examples: She announced her engagement the same day I planned to—she totally stole my thunder!
Don’t present your idea now; you’ll steal his thunder at the meeting.

idioms.definition: To pursue unrealistic dreams or goals that are unlikely to be achieved.
examples: He’s not building a business—he’s just chasing rainbows.
Stop chasing rainbows and focus on practical steps.

idioms.idiom: Throw a spanner in the works
idioms.definition: To cause a problem that disrupts plans or progress (British equivalent of 'throw a wrench in the works').
examples: His sudden resignation threw a spanner in the works of the merger.
The weather forecast threw a spanner in the works of our picnic plans.

translations.de: Einen Strich durch die Rechnung machen
translations.fr: Mettre des bâtons dans les roues

idioms.definition: To facilitate a process, often through informal means like favors or small payments.
examples: A friendly note to the clerk helped grease the gears of the permit process.
In some places, you need to grease the gears to get basic services.

idioms.definition: To go off course or deviate unexpectedly from a plan or expected behavior.
examples: The project jumped the tracks when the lead developer quit.
His comments during the interview really jumped the tracks.

idioms.definition: To operate smoothly and precisely, without problems.
examples: The event ran like clockwork thanks to her planning.
Our morning routine finally runs like clockwork.

idioms.definition: To tease or provoke someone playfully or maliciously (British English); also means to tighten a clock spring.
examples: He’s just winding you up—don’t take it seriously!
I thought she was serious, but she was winding me up the whole time.

idioms.definition: To betray or sacrifice someone else for personal gain or to avoid blame.
examples: He threw his assistant under the bus to save his own job.
Don’t throw your friends under the bus just to look good.

idioms.definition: To end a relationship or stop supporting someone, often because they are causing problems.
examples: After years of enabling him, she finally cut him loose.
The company cut the underperforming division loose.

idioms.definition: To take a risk, especially by supporting someone or something controversial.
examples: Nobody wanted to stick their neck out and defend the accused.
Thanks for sticking your neck out for me during the meeting.

idioms.definition: To support or protect someone, especially in a difficult situation.
examples: Don’t worry—I’ve got your back if things go south.
True friends always have your back.

idioms.idiom: Light at the end of the tunnel
idioms.definition: A sign of hope or improvement after a long period of difficulty.
examples: After months of unemployment, she finally saw light at the end of the tunnel.
The treatment is working—there’s light at the end of the tunnel.

idioms.definition: An encouragement to persevere through a tough situation.
examples: I know it’s hard, but hang in there—you’re almost done!
Hang in there; things will get better.

idioms.definition: In a very difficult or vulnerable position, close to defeat or failure.
examples: The company’s been on the ropes since the scandal broke.
After the injury, the champion boxer was on the ropes.

idioms.idiom: Take a shot in the dark
idioms.definition: To make a guess or attempt without having much information or any certainty of success.
examples: I don't know the answer, but I'll take a shot in the dark.
Trying to fix the car without a manual was just a shot in the dark.

translations.de: Ins Blaue raten / Einen Schuss ins Blaue wagen
translations.fr: Tenter sa chance à l'aveuglette / Y aller au jugé

idioms.definition: Despite a very low probability of success; despite very unfavorable circumstances.
examples: Against all odds, the small team won the championship.
She succeeded against all odds, starting her own business with no capital.

translations.de: Allen Widrigkeiten zum Trotz / Entgegen allen Erwartungen

idioms.definition: A person who appears friendly or harmless but is actually hostile or dangerous.
examples: Be careful of him; he seems nice, but he's a wolf in sheep's clothing.

idioms.definition: To understand the hidden meaning or implied message in something.
examples: She didn't explicitly say she was unhappy, but if you read between the lines, it was clear.

idioms.definition: To avoid becoming too friendly or intimate with someone.
examples: After their argument, she kept him at arm's length for a few weeks.

idioms.definition: A difficult person to deal with or a difficult problem to solve.
examples: Our new boss is a tough nut to crack.
This math problem is a tough nut to crack.

idioms.definition: An ambitious and energetic person who is determined to succeed.
examples: She's a real go-getter, always taking initiative at work.
We need more go-getters in our sales team.

translations.fr: Un(e) fonceur(euse) / Quelqu'un qui a la pêche.

idioms.definition: Arrogant or conceited.
examples: Ever since he won the award, he's become quite big-headed.
Don't be big-headed just because you got a promotion.

idioms.definition: An important and influential person.
examples: He's a big cheese in the advertising industry; everyone respects his opinion.

idioms.definition: A lazy person who spends a lot of time watching television.

translations.fr: Un paresseux (qui passe son temps devant la télé)

idioms.definition: Someone who is good at interacting with other people.
examples: As a sales manager, you really need to be a people person to succeed.

idioms.definition: Someone who spoils other people's fun or enthusiasm.
examples: Don't invite John to the party; he's such a wet blanket and always complains about everything.

idioms.definition: A person who is unpredictable and likely to cause damage or problems because they are not under control.
examples: His volatile temper makes him a loose cannon in negotiations.

idioms.idiom: A square peg in a round hole.

examples: He's an artist trying to work in accounting; he's truly a square peg in a round hole.

translations.fr: Ne pas être à sa place.

idioms.definition: Not perfect or refined, but with potential or good fundamental qualities.
examples: His presentation was a bit rough around the edges, but the ideas were solid.

idioms.definition: To embellish something that is already beautiful or perfect—thus spoiling it through unnecessary decoration.

examples: The film’s special effects only gilded the lily—the story was perfect as is.

translations.fr: Dorer la pilule (dans un sens esthétique)

translations.fr: En faire trop au point de gâcher

idioms.idiom: Too many cooks spoil the broth

translations.de: Zu viele Köche verderben den Brei
translations.fr: Trop de cuisiniers gâtent la sauce

idioms.definition: Be prepared and ready for action; conserve your resources until needed.

Don’t spend all your energy now—keep your powder dry for the final round.

idioms.definition: To wait patiently for the right moment to act.
examples: She’s biding her time before launching her startup.
Don’t rush—bide your time and the opportunity will come.

idioms.definition: To deliberately refrain from acting or intervening.
examples: The board sat on their hands while the company’s reputation crumbled.
Sometimes the best response is to sit on your hands and observe.

idioms.definition: Used to describe something extremely boring or slow-moving.
examples: That meeting was like watching paint dry.
I’d rather watch paint dry than listen to another budget review.

idioms.definition: An unexpected piece of good fortune.
examples: Finding that wallet was a real stroke of luck.
It was a stroke of luck that we found a parking spot right outside the restaurant.

idioms.idiom: To be down on your luck

examples: After losing his job, he was really down on his luck.
She's been a bit down on her luck recently, so let's help her out.

idioms.definition: To risk something, hoping for a positive outcome.
examples: It might rain, but I'm going to take my chances and go for a walk anyway.

idioms.definition: To achieve great success, often unexpectedly, or to win a lot of money.
examples: He really hit the jackpot when he married her.
They hit the jackpot with their new invention.

idioms.idiom: By the skin of your teeth

examples: He escaped the accident by the skin of his teeth.
We won the game by the skin of our teeth.

idioms.definition: Unlikely success experienced by a person who is new to a particular activity.

idioms.definition: Very jealous or envious.

idioms.definition: Unexpectedly; without any warning.

translations.fr: De but en blanc, à l'improviste

translations.de: Ein weißer Elefant (teurer und nutzloser Besitz)

idioms.definition: Very jealous.
examples: When I saw her new car, I was green with envy.

examples: The police caught the thief red-handed trying to escape.

translations.fr: Prendre quelqu'un la main dans le sac

idioms.definition: Caught in the act of doing something wrong or illegal.

examples: He’s on the mend after his surgery.
Her cold is on the mend, but she’s still resting.

translations.de: Auf dem Weg der Besserung sein

idioms.definition: A competitor or candidate about whom little is known but who unexpectedly wins or succeeds.
examples: The new candidate was a dark horse in the election, but he ended up winning.
She was a dark horse in the competition and surprised everyone with her talent.

idioms.idiom: The straw that broke the camel's back
idioms.definition: The final minor irritation or burden that causes an inevitable collapse or failure.
examples: Losing my keys was the straw that broke the camel's back after such a terrible day.
His rude comment was the straw that broke the camel's back; she finally quit her job.

translations.de: Der Tropfen, der das Fass zum Überlaufen bringt
translations.fr: La goutte d'eau qui fait déborder le vase

idioms.definition: In trouble or difficulty.
examples: After breaking the vase, the child was in hot water with his parents.

idioms.idiom: To have a frog in one's throat
idioms.definition: To have a hoarse voice or difficulty speaking, often due to a slight cough or dryness.
examples: I can barely speak; I have a frog in my throat this morning.
The singer had a frog in his throat during the soundcheck.

translations.fr: Avoir un chat dans la gorge

idioms.idiom: To get one's ducks in a row
idioms.definition: To organize one's thoughts, tasks, or belongings in a neat, orderly, and effective way.
examples: Before you start a business, you need to get your ducks in a row.
Let's get our ducks in a row before the big presentation tomorrow.

translations.de: Seine Angelegenheiten ordnen / Alles in Ordnung bringen
translations.fr: Mettre ses affaires en ordre / Organiser ses idées

idioms.definition: To give a false alarm; to warn of danger that is not really present, leading to people not believing you when real danger comes.
examples: He's cried wolf so many times that no one believes him now.
Don't cry wolf unless there's a real emergency.

idioms.definition: To be a very active, hardworking, and industrious person.
examples: My little sister is always a busy bee, doing homework and chores.
The entire team was a busy bee, preparing for the product launch.

translations.fr: Être une abeille affairée / Être très occupé

idioms.idiom: To open a can of worms
idioms.definition: To create or reveal a complicated problem or series of problems, which it would have been better to leave undisturbed.
examples: If you bring up that topic at the meeting, you'll open a can of worms.
Investigating the old corruption case might open a can of worms.

translations.de: Ein Fass ohne Boden öffnen / Eine Büchse der Pandora öffnen
translations.fr: Ouvrir une boîte de Pandore / Créer une multitude de problèmes

idioms.definition: A person who appears friendly or harmless but is actually dangerous or malicious.
examples: Be careful around him; he seems nice, but he's a wolf in sheep's clothing.
The new competitor appeared supportive but turned out to be a wolf in sheep's clothing, stealing our ideas.

idioms.definition: Something that will never happen.
examples: He'll pay you back your money when pigs fly.
Sure, I'll clean my room every day – when pigs fly!

translations.fr: Quand les poules auront des dents

idioms.definition: Something that is immune from criticism or questioning, often due to tradition or sentiment.
examples: The old budgeting system was a sacred cow, and no one dared to suggest changing it.
In this company, the founder's methods are a sacred cow, even if they're outdated.

idioms.definition: To eat food very quickly and hungrily.
examples: He was so hungry he wolfed down his entire meal in minutes.
After the long hike, we wolfed down our sandwiches.

idioms.idiom: Have a whale of a time
idioms.definition: To have a very enjoyable time.
examples: We had a whale of a time at the party last night!
They had a whale of a time on their vacation to the beach.

idioms.definition: To create a complicated or problematic situation that is likely to cause a lot of trouble.
examples: Discussing that controversial topic would just open a whole can of worms.
If you bring up that old issue, you'll be opening a can of worms.

idioms.definition: To suspect that something is wrong or that someone is being dishonest.
examples: When he suddenly dropped the offer, I started to smell a rat.
I smell a rat; his story doesn't add up.

idioms.idiom: A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush
idioms.definition: It's better to hold onto something you already have than to risk losing it by trying to get something better.
examples: I know the new job offer sounds exciting, but a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush, so think carefully before leaving your current stable job.
She decided to keep her small apartment rather than wait for a bigger one; a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.

translations.de: Ein Spatz in der Hand ist besser als eine Taube auf dem Dach
translations.fr: Un tiens vaut mieux que deux tu l'auras

idioms.definition: Success comes to those who prepare well and start early.
examples: If you want to get good seats, you have to arrive early. The early bird catches the worm.

translations.de: Der frühe Vogel fängt den Wurm
translations.fr: L'avenir appartient à ceux qui se lèvent tôt

idioms.definition: To be out of danger or difficulty.
examples: The patient is still recovering, but the doctors say he's finally out of the woods.
Our company isn't completely out of the woods yet, but the worst of the crisis is over.

translations.de: Aus dem Schneider sein / Über den Berg sein

idioms.definition: Something that will never happen.
examples: It'll be a cold day in hell before I apologize to him.
You'll see her admit she was wrong when hell freezes over, or on a cold day in hell.

translations.de: Wenn Ostern und Weihnachten auf einen Tag fallen / Niemals
translations.fr: Quand les poules auront des dents

idioms.definition: Someone who is very active and busy.
examples: My daughter is always a busy bee, working on her art projects.
Ever since she started her new job, she's been a busy bee, always moving from one task to another.

idioms.definition: A foolish and hopeless pursuit of something unattainable or pointless.
examples: Searching for that rare vintage toy online turned out to be a wild goose chase.
The detective realized he was on a wild goose chase after following a false lead for hours.

translations.fr: Une course folle / Une chasse à l'oie sauvage.

idioms.idiom: Get one's ducks in a row.
idioms.definition: To organize one's affairs, tasks, or plans in a proper and orderly manner.
examples: Before starting the new project, we need to get our ducks in a row.
She spent the weekend getting her ducks in a row for the upcoming business trip.

translations.de: Alles in trockenen Tüchern haben / Die Dinge in Ordnung bringen.
translations.fr: Mettre de l'ordre dans ses affaires / Organiser ses choses.

idioms.definition: A completely different matter or issue.
examples: Dealing with the client is one thing, but negotiating with the suppliers is a different kettle of fish entirely.
I thought I understood the problem, but it turned out to be a different kettle of fish.

idioms.definition: To have a very enjoyable or exciting time.
examples: We had a whale of a time at the amusement park.
They had a whale of a time on their honeymoon.

idioms.definition: Fake tears; a display of insincere sadness.
examples: Don't believe her crocodile tears; she's not really sorry.
He shed crocodile tears for his rival's misfortune.

idioms.definition: A person who is enthusiastic and hard-working.
examples: The new intern is a real eager beaver, always volunteering for extra tasks.
Don't be such an eager beaver, take a break!

translations.fr: Un bourreau de travail / Un élève modèle

idioms.idiom: Have a frog in your throat
idioms.definition: To have a sore throat or hoarseness that makes it difficult to speak clearly.
examples: Excuse me, I seem to have a frog in my throat today.
The singer cleared her throat, saying she had a frog in her throat.

translations.fr: Avoir un chat dans la gorge

idioms.idiom: Go on a wild goose chase
idioms.definition: A foolish and useless search for something.
examples: We spent all morning on a wild goose chase looking for that obscure document.
Trying to find a specific antique in all these shops felt like a wild goose chase.

idioms.definition: Someone who is uncomfortable or out of place in a particular situation.
examples: As a country boy in the big city, he felt like a fish out of water.
I felt like a fish out of water at the formal dinner party.

translations.de: Wie ein Fisch auf dem Trockenen
translations.fr: Comme un poisson hors de l'eau

idioms.definition: Someone who is unemotional, unfriendly, or distant.
examples: He's a bit of a cold fish; it's hard to get to know him personally.

idioms.definition: To be in trouble.
examples: He's in hot water with his parents for coming home so late.
After losing the important documents, she found herself in hot water at work.

translations.de: In Schwierigkeiten sein / In der Patsche sitzen

idioms.idiom: Get one's ducks in a row
idioms.definition: To get one's affairs in order; to organize things properly.
examples: Before we launch the new product, we need to get our ducks in a row.
She spent the morning getting her ducks in a row for the upcoming trip.

translations.fr: Mettre de l'ordre dans ses affaires

idioms.idiom: To have bigger fish to fry
idioms.definition: To have more important things to do.
examples: I can't worry about that small detail; I have bigger fish to fry.

idioms.definition: A relationship characterized by frequent arguments, disagreements, and strong emotions.
examples: They've always had a stormy relationship, full of ups and downs.
Their stormy relationship finally ended after years of fighting.

idioms.idiom: Like a fish out of water.
idioms.definition: Feeling uncomfortable, awkward, or out of place in an unfamiliar or unsuitable environment.
examples: At the formal party, I felt like a fish out of water in my casual clothes.
Moving to a big city after growing up in a small town, she initially felt like a fish out of water.

translations.de: Wie ein Fisch auf dem Trockenen.
translations.fr: Comme un poisson hors de l'eau.

idioms.definition: Exceptional eyesight or attention to detail.
examples: The editor has an eagle eye for typos and grammatical errors.
With an eagle eye, the security guard spotted the suspicious package.

translations.de: Ein scharfes Auge (a sharp eye), Adlerauge (eagle eye)
translations.fr: Un œil de lynx (a lynx's eye), Une vue perçante (a piercing sight)

idioms.definition: To try to make someone praise you, often by self-deprecating remarks or asking leading questions.
examples: She kept asking if her new dress looked good, clearly fishing for compliments.
He's always fishing for compliments about his cooking, even though it's delicious.

idioms.definition: A lot of anger or worry about something unimportant.
examples: Their argument about the dirty dishes was just a tempest in a teapot; it wasn't a big deal.

translations.fr: Une tempête dans un verre d'eau

idioms.definition: A person who imitates or copies the actions, style, or ideas of another.
examples: Stop being a copycat and come up with your own ideas!
The artist accused his rival of being a copycat.

idioms.definition: Why are you so quiet? (Often asked when someone is unusually silent).
examples: You haven't said a word all evening. Cat got your tongue?
When the teacher asked for volunteers, no one spoke. 'Cat got your tongue, class?' she asked.

translations.fr: Le chat t'a mangé la langue ?

idioms.definition: To imitate someone's actions without understanding why or thinking about it.
examples: The children just copied what the older kids were doing – monkey see, monkey do.
He doesn't really understand the process; he's just doing monkey see, monkey do.

translations.fr: Faire du mimétisme / Reproduire sans réfléchir

idioms.idiom: Not worth a hill of beans
idioms.definition: Completely worthless or of no importance.
examples: His apology wasn’t worth a hill of beans after what he did.
All that fame isn’t worth a hill of beans if you’re unhappy.

translations.de: Nicht das Papier wert, auf dem es steht

idioms.definition: A person’s opinion, especially when offered humbly or unsolicited.
examples: Can I give you my two cents’ worth on your presentation?
She always shares her two cents’ worth, even when no one asks.

idioms.idiom: Not worth the paper it’s written on
idioms.definition: Something (like a contract or promise) that is completely unreliable or meaningless.
examples: That warranty isn’t worth the paper it’s written on.
His assurances were not worth the paper they were written on.

translations.de: Nicht das Papier wert, auf dem es gedruckt ist

idioms.definition: Someone who boasts or appears impressive but lacks real ability, substance, or follow-through (originating in American cowboy culture).
examples: He talks about his startup like it’s the next unicorn, but he’s all hat and no cattle.
Don’t be fooled by his résumé—he’s all hat and no cattle.

idioms.definition: To organize oneself and one's affairs in a more effective way.
examples: If you don't get your act together, you'll fail the course.
He really needs to get his act together if he wants to succeed.

idioms.definition: To organize oneself and deal with things effectively.
examples: You need to get your act together if you want to pass this course.

idioms.definition: Euphemism for dying, especially suddenly or in an accident (originating from U.S. military slang).
examples: The old pilot joked he’d rather retire than buy the farm.
That reckless driver nearly bought the farm last night.

idioms.definition: To die (informal and slightly humorous).
examples: He always said he’d kick the bucket while fishing.
My phone finally kicked the bucket after five years.

idioms.definition: Dead and buried (humorous or light-hearted euphemism).
examples: If I don’t finish this report, I’ll be pushing up daisies by Friday.
Grandpa’s been pushing up daisies for ten years, but we still miss him.

translations.fr: Manger les pâquerettes par la racine

idioms.definition: To die; to face God or judgment after death.
examples: If you keep driving like that, you’ll meet your maker sooner than expected.
He lived a good life and met his maker peacefully.

idioms.definition: Dead and buried (referring to the traditional depth of a grave).
examples: After that scandal, his career was six feet under.
He’s been six feet under since 2010, but his music lives on.

idioms.definition: To surrender or admit that you can’t win.
examples: After hours of arguing, she finally waved the white flag.
The company waved the white flag and filed for bankruptcy.

idioms.definition: To retire, especially from a physically demanding job or sport.
examples: After 20 seasons, the striker hung up his boots.
He’s hanging up his boots to spend more time with his grandkids.

translations.de: Die Stiefel an den Nagel hängen

idioms.definition: To withdraw from a situation in a dignified and polite way.
examples: She bowed out gracefully when she realized the project wasn’t a fit.
After the controversy, the CEO bowed out gracefully.

idioms.definition: Completely worthless (archaic; a 'tinker' was a traveling mender of pots, and his curse was considered trivial).
examples: His promise isn’t worth a tinker’s curse—he’s broken it twice already.
That antique turned out to be not worth a tinker’s curse.

translations.de: Nicht das Papier wert, auf dem es steht

idioms.definition: To repair a damaged relationship or situation.
examples: After the argument, he tried to mend his fences with his sister.
The company is working to mend its fences with regulators.

idioms.definition: Something that happened in the past and is no longer important or worth worrying about.
examples: We argued last year, but that’s water under the bridge now.
Don’t dwell on old mistakes—they’re water under the bridge.

translations.fr: De l’eau passée sous les ponts

idioms.definition: To decide to stop thinking about or dealing with something from the past.
examples: After the settlement, she closed the book on her legal battle.
It’s time to close the book on that chapter of your life.

idioms.definition: To make a process run more smoothly, often by using informal influence or a bribe.
examples: A small donation greased the wheels and got our permit approved quickly.
In some countries, you need to grease the wheels to get anything done.

idioms.definition: Done secretly or illegally, especially involving payment to avoid taxes or regulations.
examples: He got paid under the table to avoid reporting the income.
The deal was finalized under the table, away from official records.

idioms.definition: A reserve of money used for illicit or unofficial purposes, often to bribe or influence.
examples: The investigation uncovered a slush fund used to pay off inspectors.
Politicians were accused of maintaining a slush fund for campaign favors.

idioms.definition: To make an offer or deal more attractive by adding something extra.
examples: They sweetened the pot with a signing bonus and extra vacation days.
To win the contract, we’ll need to sweeten the pot.

idioms.definition: An agreement made secretly or unofficially, bypassing normal procedures.
examples: The merger was actually a backdoor deal between two executives.
Citizens were furious about the backdoor deal that raised taxes.

idioms.definition: To go out and enjoy oneself flamboyantly, often involving partying or celebration.
examples: After graduation, we’re going to paint the town red!
They painted the town red to celebrate their 25th anniversary.

idioms.definition: To enjoy life in a lively, extravagant, or luxurious way.
examples: Now that they’re retired, they’re living it up in the Caribbean.
You only turn 30 once—live it up!

translations.fr: Profiter de la vie à fond

idioms.definition: To free oneself from constraints and behave in a wild or uninhibited way.
examples: After finals, the students cut loose at the beach house.
She finally cut loose and danced like nobody was watching.

idioms.definition: To relax and enjoy yourself without worrying about how you appear to others.
examples: Even the CEO lets her hair down at the annual retreat.
Come on—let your hair down for once!

idioms.definition: What you do is more important than what you say.
examples: She helped without being asked; actions speak louder than words.
He promised to help, but actions speak louder than words.

translations.de: Was man tut, ist wichtiger als das, was man sagt.
translations.fr: Ce que vous faites est plus important que ce que vous dites.

idioms.definition: To share juicy gossip or revealing information (modern slang, derived from LGBTQ+ and Black American Vernacular English).
examples: Come on, spill the tea—what really happened at the party?
She called me just to spill the tea about her ex.

idioms.definition: To scold or reprimand someone severely.
examples: My mom read me the riot act after I came home past curfew.
The coach read the team the riot act for their poor performance.

idioms.definition: To detain someone in conversation, often against their will.
examples: He buttonholed me in the hallway to complain about the new policy.
I tried to leave, but she buttonholed me with stories about her cat.

idioms.definition: To disillusion someone by revealing an unpleasant truth that shatters their happy illusion.
examples: I hate to burst your bubble, but that ‘investment opportunity’ is a scam.
The audit report burst the CEO’s bubble about the company’s financial health.

idioms.definition: To view something in an overly optimistic or unrealistic way.
examples: She sees her ex through rose-colored glasses, forgetting all the fights.
Don’t look at the startup through rose-colored glasses—check the cash flow.

idioms.definition: An event that alerts someone to a problem and prompts them to take action.
examples: The heart attack was a wake-up call to quit smoking.
The data breach served as a wake-up call for cybersecurity reform.

idioms.definition: To discourage or dampen enthusiasm for an idea or plan.
examples: His criticism poured cold water on our proposal.
Don’t pour cold water on her dreams—encourage her instead.

idioms.definition: To deliberately ostracize or ignore someone, especially by a group (British idiom with historical roots).
examples: After he reported the safety violations, his coworkers sent him to Coventry.
The club quietly sent her to Coventry after the scandal.

idioms.definition: To exclude someone from a group or organization by voting against them, often secretly.
examples: He was blackballed from the club after his controversial remarks.
In the old days, one ‘black ball’ in the voting box was enough to blackball a candidate.

idioms.definition: To deliberately avoid or reject someone, often for moral or social reasons.
examples: The community shunned him after he broke their trust.
Some religious groups shun former members who leave.

idioms.definition: To completely ignore someone as if they don’t exist, especially in public (British English).
examples: She cut him dead in the hallway after their argument.
At the gala, he was cut dead by everyone who once called him a friend.

translations.fr: Faire comme si quelqu’un n’existait pas

idioms.definition: A small, visible part of a much larger or more serious problem.
examples: The data breach was just the tip of the iceberg—internal corruption ran deep.
Her lateness is the tip of the iceberg; she’s completely disengaged.

idioms.definition: The minimum number of staff needed to keep an operation running, often during holidays or emergencies.
examples: Only a skeleton crew works at the office over Christmas.
The hospital ran on a skeleton crew during the storm.

idioms.definition: A rough estimate or approximate number, not precise.
examples: Can you give me a ballpark figure for the cost of the renovation?
I don't have the exact sales numbers, but a ballpark figure would be around 500 units.

idioms.definition: Creative ideas that are not limited by current thinking or beliefs; thinking outside the box without practical constraints.
examples: For this session, we need some true blue-sky thinking; no idea is too wild.
The goal of the workshop was to encourage blue-sky thinking for future product development.

idioms.definition: To waste time and energy on futile or repetitive activities without making progress.
examples: I’ve been chasing my tail all day trying to find that file.
Without a plan, you’ll just chase your tail and get nowhere.

idioms.definition: To expend effort without achieving results, like a car stuck in mud.
examples: We’re just spinning our wheels arguing about this minor detail.
If you don’t change your strategy, you’ll keep spinning your wheels.

idioms.definition: To discuss or do something repeatedly without reaching a conclusion or solution.
examples: The committee has been going around in circles for weeks.
We keep going around in circles—let’s bring in a mediator.

idioms.definition: Attempting something completely futile or pointless; effort guaranteed to fail.
examples: Trying to reason with him is like pissing in the wind.
Don’t waste your breath—this policy change is pissing in the wind.

idioms.definition: Everything that is possible or required; the whole thing, often with a sense of completeness or boldness.
examples: We didn’t just repaint the house—we went the full monty with new floors, lighting, and furniture.
He didn’t hold back; it was the full monty performance.

idioms.definition: Everything involved in a situation or activity; the entire affair.
examples: We’re selling the house, the car, the dog—the whole shebang.
He didn’t just fix the bug; he rewrote the whole shebang.

idioms.definition: Every part of something; entirely and completely.
examples: They bought the company lock, stock, and barrel.
She moved to Paris, lock, stock, and barrel—cat, plants, and all.

idioms.definition: Including all flaws or imperfections; without hiding anything negative.
examples: He accepted the job offer, warts and all.
This biography tells his story warts and all.

idioms.definition: Every tiny bit or detail; absolutely everything, down to the smallest element.
examples: She remembered every last iota of the conversation.
I cleaned the kitchen—every last iota of it.
